Editor’s choice paper A density functional theory based elementary reaction mechanism for early steps of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over cobalt catalyst. 1. Reaction kinetics Alireza Asiaee Kenneth M. Benjamin ⁎ Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, 501 E. Saint Joseph St., Rapid City, SD 57701, USA Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering South Dakota School of Mines and Technology 501 E. Saint Joseph St. Rapid City SD 57701 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), an efficient process for production of valuable fuel products from synthesized gas (syngas), has been the subject of many theoretical and experimental studies for decades. This work involves detailed molecular and microkinetic modeling of this catalytic process. By adopting an existing elementary reaction mechanism in the literature, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been applied to model the kinetics and thermodynamics of FTS elementary steps on a flat Co(0001) catalyst surface. In this regard, using the DFT generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and canonical transition state theory, the rate constants and the activation energies of individual elementary reactions have been calculated. In addition, the necessity for modification of the existing proposed elementary steps and considerations of alternative mechanisms have been probed. Finally, it was determined that the favorable path for CO dissociation, as one of the key steps in the FTS, occurs through a hydrogen-assisted mechanism and the estimated rate parameters have been compared with those of other theoretical studies. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Reaction mechanism Kinetic parameters estimation Density functional theory calculation 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), known as the most common technique for conversion of gas to liquid (GTL), is a heterogeneous chemical process where syngas, a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, converts to valuable hydrocarbon products. Since the invention of the process back in the 1920s, numerous experimental and theoretical studies have been conducted toward the improvement and modeling of FTS [1,2]. Generally, a better understanding of the reaction pathways for a chemical process can be achieved through studying the associated elementary steps. However, due to the complexity of the surface reactions and the wide range of intermediates and products [3–6], the actual mechanism of FTS is still under discussion [7]. Assuming that the chain growth and the hydrocarbon product distribution can be mathematically described by the Anderson-Schulz-Flory polymerization mechanism, some studies obtained their microkinetic models for production of light hydrocarbon products from syngas through computer generated reaction networks [8,9]. However, the majority of suggested microkinetic mechanisms for FTS are empirical and semi-empirical models which have been developed in order to match the experimental results [10–14]. From a different point of view, some more recent theoretical studies have tried to look into the FTS mechanism at molecular and atomistic levels [7,15]. One of the provided micro-detailed models describing the mechanism of FTS, from syngas adsorption on the catalyst surface along with extensive surface reaction pathways and hydrocarbon formation up to C2 products, is the one suggested by Storsæter et al. [11]. Initially, they considered a total number of 71 reversible elementary steps, including the carbide mechanism, CO insertion mechanism, and water-gas-shift (WGS) reactions, and calculated all the required kinetic parameters of each step using the unity bond index-quadratic exponential potential (UBI-QEP) method. Then, they reduced their model to 26 elementary reactions (Table 1 ) and adjusted the estimated rate parameters to match experimental data. In the provided reactions, free active sites on the catalyst surface are shown by stars (*), while the chemical formulas with one or two * superscriptions represent the species in the adsorbed state on the catalyst surface occupying single or double active sites, respectively. In addition to the experimental methods, theoretical simulation of surface reactions in heterogeneous process has become an area of intense activity over the past two decades. Advances in quantum calculations have provided efficient tools and methods in order to model catalytic reactions with results which are in great agreement with experimental observations [16]. Several density functional theory (DFT) studies have been conducted toward simulating the adsorption of reactants and their activation in FTS [17–21]. Some other studies have tried to probe the FTS mechanism further in detail by modeling surface reactions quantum mechanically [12,13,22–25]. For instance, Zhuo et al. [26] and Ojeda et al. [27] applied DFT calculations for evaluating the energy barriers of different suggested CO dissociation mechanisms for FTS. They compared the DFT results in order to distinguish the most probable pathway for CO activation on heterogeneous catalyst surfaces from energetic perspectives. The studied mechanisms were divided into the two general categories of direct dissociation of CO molecule and hydrogen-assisted CO activation. Although both of these studies suggest that the formation of CHO* intermediate on the FTS catalyst surfaces is energetically more favorable, the subsequent steps, as further hydrogenation of CHO* toward formation of CH2O* or CHOH* intermediates, still require more investigation. In spite of all previous efforts, due to the high computational cost of quantum mechanics calculations, not many investigations have conducted a thorough study of different FTS mechanisms by evaluating all the rate parameters (such as rate constant) for the individual elementary reactions. These data can be used in advance, via micro-kinetic modeling, to compare the product distribution and selectivity of different reaction pathways under various operating conditions. As the considered FTS mechanism in this study, the suggested elementary reactions by Storsæter et al. are combined with the other proposed mechanisms for CO activation. Using the DFT method DMol and canonical transition state theory, all the elementary steps have been characterized under the common industrial temperature of 220°C (493K) [1,7,28]. The rate constants and the activation energies of the individual elementary reactions are presented, and the most probable reaction paths for CO conversion are discussed from both kinetic and thermodynamic viewpoints. 2 Computational methods In DFT studies of heterogeneous catalysis, various numbers of catalyst layers have been suggested for precise modeling. Although considering more layers may result in more accurate outcomes, it was shown that simulation of four layers of metal atoms with the two top layers relaxed is normally sufficient [29]. Thus, the catalyst slab used for DFT simulation in the current study contains 4 layers of p(3×3) Co atoms in the crystalline structure configuration of Co(0001). Allowing for periodic boundary conditions, this slab (representing the active site in reactions when there is no adsorbate on the surface) provides a surface coverage of 1/9 monolayer (ML) for the adsorbed species occupying a single active site on the catalyst surface. The thickness of the vacuum slab over the surface was set at 10Å. This value is large enough to neglect the effect of interactions from the periodic cell in the vertical direction [26]. During all performed simulations, the Co atoms in the bottom two layers were fixed at their optimized positions (with minimum energy level) determined by DFT calculation of the clean surface, while the top two layers were allowed to relax. In this work, all DFT simulations were carried out with the DMol3 program of BIOVIA’s Materials Studio [30], where the DFT method of Perdew-Wang generalized-gradient approximation (GGA-PW91) was applied [31]. In order to reduce the computational cost, DFT semi-core pseudopotentials (DSPP) were considered in which the core electrons are replaced by a single effective potential. Also, because of the ferromagnetic nature of cobalt, spin polarization was applied in the calculations. For evaluating the activation energies (in both forward and reverse direction) of each reaction, two types of DFT calculations were performed. First, the lowest energetic configurations of all reactants and products were determined via geometry optimization calculation. Then, using these refined structures, the transition states and their energy levels were found. The later calculation method, known as transition state (TS) search, is a combination of linear synchronous transit (LST) and quadratic synchronous transit (QST) methods. The LST method starts with an interpolation between the reactant and product to find a maximum energy level, followed by an energy minimization toward the considered directions of the reaction pathway. Afterward, using the approximated TS structure, QST maximization performs TS refinement to a higher degree, which is followed by another conjugate gradient minimization. The LST/QST cycle is repeating until the considered criteria of convergence are achieved [32]. In addition to evaluating the energy barriers, in order to estimate the rate constants for each reversible elementary reaction, the geometry optimization and the TS search calculations were followed by frequency calculations. The pre-exponential term in the rate constants were evaluated via canonical transition state theory using the calculated vibrational frequencies and moments of inertia. In the calculations of geometry optimization, the maximum energy tolerance was considered as 1.0×10−5 Ha, while the maximum displacement of atoms was less than 5.0×10−3 Å and the maximum value of force was lower than 2.0×10−3 Ha/Å. The tolerance for self-consistent field (SCF) convergence was set to be less than 1.0×10−6 Ha. In order to find the transition states, the convergence criteria were set as 2.0×10−3 Ha/Å and 1.0×10−6 Ha for the root mean square (RMS) deviation of force and the SCF tolerance, respectively. However, due to the sensitivity of these calculations, the TS search of some reactions did not meet all the above convergence criteria. For these reactions the root mean square (RMS) deviation and the SCF tolerance were set to be less than 1.0×10−2 Ha/Å and 1.0×10−5 Ha, respectively. By applying Monkhorst-Pack grids [33], the density of k-points was kept below 0.05Å−1 in all cases. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorbed species stable structures In addition to the clean catalyst surface, there are 19 other intermediate species involved in the suggested FT reaction mechanism by Storsæter et al. (Table 1). For species occupying a single active site, there are 4 different adsorption sites on the Co(0001) catalyst surface (Fig. 1 ). However, not all the adsorbed species are stable on all the sites. While some of the adsorbates are stable on all four types of active sites, many others are stable only on specific positions. A summary of the stable configurations and the relative energies of the species adsorbed on single active sites are provided in Table 2 . The most stable configuration for each adsorbed intermediate is given a relative energy of zero and unstable configurations are denoted by dashed-lines. As shown in Table 2, the most stable spot on the catalyst surface varies for different intermediates. Despite the difference in the surface coverages (which is considered as 1/9 ML in this study), the calculated most stable configuration for CO*, C*, O*, and H* species are in good agreement with other DFT studies [20,21,34–36]. For some of the species, such as H* and CH3*, the energy difference between fcc and hcp positions are very close. Thus, it can be concluded that both sites are almost equally favorable. The calculation results of geometry optimization show that the four oxygenated species of CHO*, CH2O*, CH3CO*, and CH3CHO* can be adsorbed on the Co(0001) surface through different interactive atoms. As it is shown in Fig. 2 , one stable configuration is adsorbing through the oxygen atom, occupying a single active site on the surface. The other stable configuration, which occupies two active sites, is binding to the surface through both oxygen and carbon atoms in the carbonyl group (Table 3 ). By comparing the energy levels of the configurations, the oxygenate species binding with two active sites are more stable with about −20 to −200kJ/mol lower energy levels. Additionally, the calculated geometry optimized structures of CHO and CH2O are in good agreement with the configurations suggested by Zhuo et al. [26]. Therefore, for these species the most stable configurations (occupying two active sites) are considered in the reaction mechanism of this current study. The DFT calculated configurations with lowest energy levels of all species occupying two active sites on the catalyst surface are provided in Table 3. Based on the resulted geometry optimized configuration of CH3CH3**, it appears that the saturated C2H6 compound is not stable on the surface in an adsorbed state. Hence, the CH3CH3** species and its corresponding elementary reaction of desorption should be eliminated from the considered FTS mechanism (originally provided by Storsaeter). In the suggested FTS mechanism, only a few steps have one adsorbed species as reactant or product in their elementary reaction. For the rest of reactions, the considered optimized configurations to find the TS must have two adsorbates on the p(3×3) Co(0001) surface. As a consequence, the neighboring effect may alter the favorable sites of adsorbates. This reconfiguration due to neighboring/lateral interactions was only seen for CO*, where in the presence of another adsorbate it preferred the hcp position over the atop position. This behavior of CO* adsorbate on a cobalt surface has been reported in another theoretical study by Pick [37]. However, in the presence of O* coadsorbate, the CO* species still chose the atop position rather than the other adsorption sites. 3.2 Modifying the reaction network As noted earlier, in addition to the 26 elementary reaction steps suggested by Storsæter et al. (Table 1), the following 4 additional reactions were considered in the current study in order to find the most probable mechanism of CO activation from both energetic and kinetic aspects. CO*+*↔C*+O* CHO**↔CH*+O* CHO**+H*↔CHOH*+2* CHOH*+*↔CH*+OH* The first reaction describes direct dissociation of CO*, while the other three reactions consider hydrogen-assisted CO activation via formation of CHO* intermediate. In this study, the most stable configuration of CHOH* in the adsorbed state was calculated as it is shown in Fig. 3 , where the carbon atom bonds with the cobalt surface at the fcc position. In the previous subsection, it has been discussed that the unstable intermediate of CH3CH3** should be eliminated from the considered mechanism. Therefore, the following alternative reaction, which has been suggested in other FT microkinetic models [8,9,14], was considered instead of elementary steps of 23 and 25 in Table 1. CH3CH2*+H*↔C2H6 +2* Another required modification to the Storsæter et al. micro-mechanism is the balancing of active sites in the elementary reaction steps involving the 4 intermediates of CHO*, CH2O*, CH3CO*, and CH3CHO*, as they occupy two active sites instead of one. The corrected reactions are as follows: CO*+H*↔CHO** CHO**+H*↔CH2O**+* CH2O**+H*↔CH3O*+2* CH3*+CH2O**↔CH3CH2O*+2* CH3*+CO*↔CH3CO** CH3CO**+H*↔CH3CHO**+* CH3CHO**+H*↔CH3CH2O*+2* 3.3 Evaluation of rate constant parameters Considering the rate constant of each elementary step via the Arrhenius equation, (1), k = A o exp ( − E a R T ) the DFT calculation results were applied to evaluate the activation energy, Ea , and the pre-exponential factor, Ao , for each surface reaction through transition state theory (TST). The parameter Ea is simply the difference between the energy level of TS and that of reactant and product for the forward and reverse elementary reactions, respectively. The pre-exponential factor of reaction i (Ao ,i ) was calculated by (2), A o , i = ( k B T h ) ( q T S q i ) where T is the reaction temperature and kB and h are the Boltzmann and Plank constants, respectively. In Eq. (2), qTS denotes the partition function of TS and qi represents the partition function of reactants in reaction i, where during calculations, all the reactant species of the elementary step i were imbedded in a single structure (due to requirements for TS search procedure in the DMol3 program). Theoretically, each partition function can be calculated as the product of three different motional formats of translational, rotational, and vibrational partition functions. Many studies have discussed that for surface reactions, because of the constraint in atom movement, the ratio of translational and rotational portions in qTS /qi is very close to unity, and the majority of variation in rate constants for different surface reactions is due to the ratio of vibrational partition functions [38–40]. However, the DFT results of our current study show that for some larger oxygenate intermediates, considering the rotational partition functions may cause up to 10% variation in the value of rate constants. The various partition functions were obtained using the following equations [41]. (3), q trans 3 D = ( 2 π m k B T h 2 ) 3 / 2 V (4), q rot = ( π I x I y I z ) 1 / 2 σ ( 8 π 2 k B T h 2 ) 3 / 2 (5), q v i b = ∏ j = 1 M ( exp ( − h v j 2 k B T ) 1 − exp ( − h v j k B T ) ) where subscripts trans, rot, and vib stand for translational, rotational, and vibrational modes of the partition function, respectively. The 3-dimensional (3D) translational partition function was considered only in the adsorption and desorption elementary steps. In Eq. (3), m is the mass of adsorbed species and V was considered as the volume of the vacuum slab above the catalyst surface. The three momentums of inertia in each direction of Cartesian coordination are denoted by I, while the σ in Eq. (4) represents the rotational symmetry number which is normally equal to 1 (confirmed for all the species and transition states in this current study). In the vibrational partition function (Eq. (5)), vj represents the frequency of normal mode j. The value of M as the total number of all considered normal modes is less than 3N, where N is the number of all atoms, including adsorbed species and metal surface ones, in the structure under study. The normal modes with negative or small frequency values were not considered in calculations. Since a negative frequency value indicates an imaginary mode associated with the negative curvature of reaction coordination of TS and the small values represent the frequencies of rotational and translational modes, these values must be taken out of vibrational calculations [42]. Regarding the adsorption (desorption) steps, several approaches has been suggested in order to obtain the values of rate constants. A common method is calculation of the adsorption rate constant from collision theory [38,43]. Another approach is calculating the pre-exponential factor of the rate constant for the desorption step using the partition functions of adsorbate in the gas phase and adsorbed state and then evaluating the adsorption rate constant from the equilibrium constant (using microscopic reversibility) [39,40]. However, applying the later approach for the reactions of this current study resulted in overestimating the pre-exponential factors with orders of more than 1012 and 1017 s−1 for adsorption and desorption steps, respectively. Therefore, the following simplified alternative was used in order to estimate the pre-exponential factor of adsorption rate constants: (6), A 0 , a d s = ( k B T h ) ( q * q g a s ) where the qgas and q* are the partition functions of adsorbate species in the gas phase and adsorbed state, respectively. It is shown that this approach can be analogous with collision theory, where (through expansion of Eq. (6)), kBT/h × qtran 2D /qtran 3D stands for the collision frequency and qvib */qrotqvibqtran 2D expresses the sticking coefficient [41]. Here, qtran 2D represents the 2-dimensional transition motions of adsorbed species over the catalyst surface. Consequently, the desorption rate constant (kdes ) for these reactions can be calculated from that of adsorption (kads ) and the equilibrium constant (KC,ads ) as follows: (7), K C , a d s = k a d s k d e s = exp ( − Δ G a d s R T ) where the Gibbs energy of adsorption (ΔGads. ), can be calculated from adsorption energy and entropy changes (ΔEads and ΔSads ), respectively, as outlined below: (8). Δ G a d s = Δ H a d s − T Δ S a d s = Δ E a d s + P Δ V a d s − T Δ S a d s = Δ E a d s − R T − T Δ S a d s In derivation of Eq. (8), the ideal gas condition was assumed, where ΔVads = Vgas . The required correlations for evaluating the transitional, rotational, and vibrational contributions of ΔSads are provided in the work of Ojeda et al. [23]. The calculated rate parameters for the considered mechanism in this study are provided in Table 4 . In spite of the bond cleavage during adsorption of hydrogen molecule on Co(0001), the current DFT calculation did not spot a maximum energy level (identified TS) along the reaction coordinates. Consequently, the adsorption of H2 was considered as barrier-less, which has been suggested in some of the previous microkinetic modeling studies [8,14]. Additionally, despite the difference in the considered surface coverages, the calculated energy of H2 adsorption fits well with the other provided theoretical values [35,36]. A comparison of the calculated energy values for other reactions with some available data in the literature is provided in Table 5 . Considering the differences in the surface coverages and implemented DFT methods, the majority of the current calculated reaction energies and activation barriers are in good agreement with the results of other theoretical studies. However, the ranges of the reported values for some of the elementary reactions are considerably wide. In some cases (elementary steps 5, 11, 27, and 28), the calculated reaction thermodynamics (endothermicity versus exothermicity) were evaluated in opposite directions. These crucial disagreements between different theoretical studies are mainly due to the differences in the considered structures of intermediates. Even a slight difference in the geometry of intermediate species may alter the modeled reaction path and consequently changes the energy level of TS and reaction barriers. 3.4 CO dissociation mechanisms CO bond scission is known as one of the key steps in the mechanism of FTS [26]. The variations in energy and free energy through different CO dissociation mechanisms are presented in Figs. 4 and 5 , respectively. Although Gunasooriya et al. performed their calculations using a plane-wave basis set on a different crystalline structure of Co(111), the trends and the magnitudes of energy variations calculated in this study and provided in Fig. 4 are significantly in agreement with their results for similar elementary reactions [48]. Despite the lower energy level of the products from direct splitting results of CO bond cleavage (C*+O*) in comparison with the other first intermediates (Fig. 4), the H-assisted mechanism followed by CHO** conversion to CH*+O* turned to be the most favorable path due to its noticeably lower values of barriers. In addition, the final product’s energy level in the latter mechanism supports this statement, since its relative value is almost half of that in the other H-assisted pathway. Based on these results and in contrast to what was suggested by Ojeda et al. [27], because of the larger activation energies, CHOH* intermediate formation and its corresponding reaction mechanism is not as favorable as the other suggested mechanism. This disagreement is mainly due to the different considered refined geometrical position of adsorbed CHO** species in this study (Table 3), whereas Ojeda et al. assumed a different configuration for CHO* intermediate occupying a single active site (see Table 5 for comparison of activation barriers and reaction energy values). While CHO* intermediate (where it occupies a single active site) can be simply hydrogenated to CHOH* by a bond formation between the O and H atoms, the considered CHO** hydrogenation requires an additional OCo bond cleavage which results in relatively larger magnitude of activation energy for the corresponding elementary reaction. On the other hand, as it is shown in Table 5, the estimated values for the barriers of the other elementary reactions involving CHO** species not only have a good agreement with the corresponding energy values provided in the works by Zhuo et al. [26] and Cheng et al. [45], but these values also agree with some (e.g. step 10) of the other computational studies, including the ones which considered single occupancy of an active site for this intermediate (CHO*). The relative free energy change (ΔG) of each reaction in Fig. 5 was calculated from surface rate parameters at 493K using Eq. (8). The free energy profile of different CO dissociation mechanisms follows the same trend as the energy profile (Fig. 4). Despite the differences between magnitudes of ΔG and ΔE values, it appears that the variations in free energy change of these reactions are largely controlled by energy changes rather than entropic contributions. Considering the fact that a larger positive value of ΔG means the mechanism is thermodynamically less favorable, it can be confirmed that the CO* bond cleavage as CO*+H*→CHO**→CH*+O* is the most probable path during FTS over the Co(0001) catalyst surface. The total ΔG variation of this mechanism is about +31.9kJ/mol, while its intermediate (CHO**) free energy level with a value of +58.7kJ/mol is not much higher than that of the products from other mechanisms. Regarding the thermodynamics of the other reaction pathways, direct dissociation of CO (CO*→C*+O*) and the H-assisted mechanism suggested by Ojeda et al. are almost equally favorable. However, based on the energy profile (Fig. 4) of the reactions, the reactants in the latter mechanism should pass through a TS with an energy barrier twice as large as the one in direct dissociation mechanism. Additionally, it is clear that the suggested reaction of CO*+H*→C*+OH* in the original Storsæter et al. model is favorable from neither kinetic nor thermodynamic points of view. 4 Conclusion A previously provided FTS microkinetic model has been modified by considering other suggested mechanisms for CO activation and updated using parameters directly from quantum chemical calculations. The rate constants and the activation energies of individual elementary steps (both adsorption and surface reactions) have been evaluated using first-principle DFT calculations. Several important factors, such as determining the most stable configuration for each adsorbed species and surface reactants neighboring effects, have been considered in order to improve the accuracy of estimated rate parameters. The results have been compared with those of other theoretical studies found in the literature. Furthermore, an investigation of the dominating CO dissociation mechanism, one of the key steps in process of FTS, was conducted. The calculations identified different desired adsorption spots on Co(0001) catalyst surface for different adsorbed species involved in the mechanism. In addition, it was concluded that saturated C2H6 is not stable on the catalyst surface in an adsorbed state and its adsorption process is associated with a CH bond cleavage. Therefore, the corresponding elementary steps from the original model were modified to exclude the adsorbed CH3CH3** intermediate. Additional corrections were applied due to balancing the number total active sites in each reaction, where the number of occupied sites by adsorbate was different from that in the original model. Lastly, the DFT calculations indicated that the most probable path for the conversion of CO in the adsorbed state is through formation of CHO* intermediate followed by its dissociation into CH* and O* species. coredata.dc:description: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), an efficient process for production of valuable fuel products from synthesized gas (syngas), has been the subject of many theoretical and experimental studies for decades. This work involves detailed molecular and microkinetic modeling of this catalytic process. By adopting an existing elementary reaction mechanism in the literature, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been applied to model the kinetics and thermodynamics of FTS elementary steps on a flat Co(0001) catalyst surface. In this regard, using the DFT generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and canonical transition state theory, the rate constants and the activation energies of individual elementary reactions have been calculated. In addition, the necessity for modification of the existing proposed elementary steps and considerations of alternative mechanisms have been probed. Finally, it was determined that the favorable path for CO dissociation, as one of the key steps in the FTS, occurs through a hydrogen-assisted mechanism and the estimated rate parameters have been compared with those of other theoretical studies.
coredata.dc:title: A density functional theory based elementary reaction mechanism for early steps of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over cobalt catalyst. 1. Reaction kinetics
